name: Lune Croissanterie
summary: Described by the New York Times as making 'the finest croissants in the world'. The warehouse setting looks like an Apple store for pastry. Despite lines at 7 AM and high prices ($10+ per pastry), the engineering perfection of the dough justifies the hype.

red_flags.evidence: "If you arrive after 10am, the specials are gone. Frustrating." (Broadsheet)
"$14 for a twice-baked croissant is steep, even for Melbourne." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The lamination is scientifically perfect. Shatteringly crisp." (New York Times)
"Watching the chefs work in the glass cube is mesmerizing theater." (Good Food)

sample_reviews.text: I wanted to hate it because of the hype. I failed. The almond croissant is a masterpiece.
Good, but not 'wait in the rain for an hour' good. It's just butter and flour.

embedding_text: Lune Croissanterie in Melbourne, Australia. cafe. local_gem. 'Finest croissants in the world'. Warehouse setting, high prices, and early lines. Engineering perfection of the dough justifies the hype. Red flags: Sold out early, Expensive pastry. Positives: Technical perfection, The 'Cube' experience.

name: Fergburger
summary: A burger joint with a cult following so large the queue often blocks the sidewalk. While the burgers are massive (size of a plate) and tasty, locals argue the 45+ minute wait isn't worth it when neighboring Devil Burger is just as good.

red_flags.evidence: "Line is insane at all hours. You wait 45 mins just to order." (Lonely Planet)
"Locals go to Devil Burger or Red Star. Same quality, no line." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The Fergburger is the size of a human head. Great value." (Travel Blog)
"Waiting in line with a beer is part of the Queenstown experience." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Overhyped. The bun fell apart and it was just a big burger. Go next door.
Best burger I've ever had after a hike. The 'Cockadoodle Oink' is legendary.

embedding_text: Fergburger in Queenstown, New Zealand. restaurant. mixed. Cult burger joint with massive lines. Burgers are huge and tasty, but locals prefer Devil Burger to avoid the 45-minute wait. Red flags: The Queue, Better alternatives exist. Positives: Huge portions, Social vibe.

name: Burj Khalifa (At The Top)
summary: The tallest building in the world charges a fortune ($50-$150) for an elevator ride. The standard 'At The Top' ticket only goes to floor 124, while the 'SKY' ticket (floor 148) costs double. Views are often obscured by haze or sandstorms.

red_flags.evidence: "You pay premium for 'At The Top' but you are only halfway up the building." (Arabian Business)
"Queued for 1 hour to go up, and 1 hour to come down." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "You can say you stood on the world's tallest building." (Lonely Planet)
"The elevator ride itself is an engineering marvel, moving 10m/sec." (Official Site)

sample_reviews.text: A view of sand and highways. Not worth the money or the wait.
Go at sunset. Seeing the fountains from above is cool.

embedding_text: Burj Khalifa (At The Top) in Dubai, UAE. attraction. tourist_trap. Tallest building in world. expensive elevator ride ($50+) to a deck that isn't the top. Haze often obscures views. Red flags: Deceptive marketing, Lines everywhere. Positives: Bragging rights, Fast elevator.

name: Mahane Yehuda Market
summary: The 'Shuk' is the beating heart of Jerusalem. By day, a chaotic produce market; by night, a trendy bar scene. While some stalls are gentrifying and raising prices, the energy and food quality (halva, rugelach) remain authentic.

red_flags.evidence: "Friday afternoon before Shabbat is a crush. Avoid if you have anxiety." (TimeOut Israel)
"Stalls at the main entrance charge double. Go deep inside." (Local Guide)

positive_signals.evidence: "The way it turns into a bar scene at night is unique in the world." (Eater)
"The chocolate rugelach from Marzipan Bakery are gooey perfection." (Serious Eats)

sample_reviews.text: Best vibes in the city. Grab a beer and sit on a crate.
Crowded and loud, but the food is incredible. Try the Iraqi Kubbeh.

embedding_text: Mahane Yehuda Market in Jerusalem, Israel. market. local_gem. Chaotic produce market by day, trendy bar scene by night. Authentic energy and food (halva, rugelach) despite some gentrification. Red flags: Aggressive crowds (Friday), Tourist pricing at entrances. Positives: Nightlife transformation, Marzipan Rugelach.

name: Alcatraz Night Tour
summary: While Alcatraz is a major attraction, the 'Night Tour' is a distinct, superior experience. It is limited capacity, includes areas closed during the day (like the hospital), and features compelling guided talks. Locals actually recommend this.

red_flags.evidence: "Tickets sell out 3 months in advance. Impossible to get last minute." (SF Gate)
"It is freezing on the island at night. Dress for winter." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "Fewer people and the sunset over the Golden Gate make it hauntingly beautiful." (Lonely Planet)
"The audio tour voiced by former inmates is chilling and award-winning." (Travel Channel)

sample_reviews.text: I'm an SF native and I've done the night tour 3 times. It never gets old.
Spooky, informative, and amazing views of the city lights. Worth the planning.

embedding_text: Alcatraz Night Tour in San Francisco, USA. tour. local_gem. Distinct from day tour. Limited capacity, access to closed areas, and haunting atmosphere. Locals recommend it. Red flags: Hard to book, Cold/Windy. Positives: Spooky and intimate, Excellent audio guide.

name: Fisherman's Wharf
summary: The epicenter of SF tourism and arguably the worst food in the city. Souvenir shops selling 'fog' in a can, overpriced clam chowder in stale bread bowls, and aggressive buskers. Locals treat it like a quarantine zone.

red_flags.evidence: "Restaurants here serve frozen seafood to people who don't know better." (SF Chronicle)
"Busker scares people for money. Aggressive panhandling." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The sea lions are actually cute and free to watch." (Lonely Planet)
"The antique arcade museum is the only redeeming quality." (Atlas Obscura)

sample_reviews.text: Avoid unless you want to be surrounded by slow walkers and overpriced trash.
Fun for the kids to see the sea lions, but we ate elsewhere.

embedding_text: Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco, USA. attraction. tourist_trap. Epicenter of SF tourism. Souvenir shops, overpriced stale chowder, and aggressive buskers. Locals avoid. Red flags: Terrible food quality, Bushman scam. Positives: Sea Lions at Pier 39, Musee Mecanique.

name: Swan Oyster Depot
summary: A counter-only seafood institution since 1912. There is always a line, it closes early, and the staff are brusque, but the Dungeness crab and sashmi are undeniably fresh. It is the antithesis of Fisherman's Wharf.

red_flags.evidence: "Expect to wait 1-2 hours in line on Polk Street." (Eater SF)
"Closes at 5:30pm. Lunch only basically." (Google Maps)

positive_signals.evidence: "The crab back (fat) dip is the best seafood bite in the city." (Anthony Bourdain)
"No reservations, cash only, banter with the servers. Real SF." (Bon Appetit)

sample_reviews.text: Worth the wait. The Sicilian sashimi is to die for.
Expensive for a counter, but the quality is unmatched.

embedding_text: Swan Oyster Depot in San Francisco, USA. restaurant. local_gem. Counter-only seafood institution since 1912. Long lines and limited hours, but Dungeness crab is unmatched. Antithesis of Fisherman's Wharf. Red flags: The wait, Limited hours. Positives: Freshness, Old school vibe.

name: Museum of Ice Cream
summary: The pioneer of the 'Instagram Museum'. It is not a museum; it is a series of colorful backdrops for selfies with a sprinkle pool made of plastic. Tickets are expensive ($40+) and the 'free' ice cream samples are small and generic.

red_flags.evidence: "It's a selfie factory disguised as culture. Zero educational value." (New York Times)
"The sprinkle pool is full of hair and bandaids. Disgusting." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "Designed perfectly for your TikTok feed. Colors are popping." (Influencer Blog)
"My 6-year-old loved the slide and the pink room." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Overpriced photo booth. The ice cream was mediocre. Felt gross in the pool.
If you want cute photos, it's great. If you want ice cream, go to Van Leeuwen.

embedding_text: Museum of Ice Cream in New York, USA. attraction. tourist_trap. 'Selfie factory' with colorful backdrops and plastic sprinkle pool. Not a museum. Expensive tickets, generic ice cream samples. Red flags: Not a museum, Sprinkle pool grossness. Positives: Visual candy, Fun for kids.

name: Gordon Ramsay Hell's Kitchen
summary: A theme park restaurant for fans of the TV show. While the Beef Wellington is consistent, the prices are sky-high for what is essentially a chain restaurant experience. You are paying for the logo and the pitchfork decor.

red_flags.evidence: "$70 for a piece of beef in puff pastry because Ramsay's face is on the menu." (Eater Vegas)
"It feels like an assembly line. Food comes out too fast to be special." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "The Wellington is cooked perfectly every time. Reliable." (Food Blog)
"Fun if you love the show. The kitchen layout matches the set." (Yelp)

sample_reviews.text: The scallops were rubbery. Just a marketing gimmick.
Bucket list for my husband. Food was good, bill was painful.

embedding_text: Gordon Ramsay Hell's Kitchen in Las Vegas, USA. restaurant. tourist_trap. Theme park restaurant for TV show fans. Consistent Beef Wellington, but sky-high prices for assembly-line experience. Red flags: Celebrity tax, Mass produced. Positives: Consistent Wellington, Show immersion.

name: Guy Fieri's Vegas Kitchen
summary: The culinary equivalent of a monster truck rally. The 'Trash Can Nachos' are a viral hit, but the food is excessively greasy, salty, and overpriced. It caters exclusively to tourists wanting excess over quality.

red_flags.evidence: "I felt my arteries clogging. It's just salt and fat." (Yelp)
"$20 for a burger that tastes like Wendy's." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The presentation of the nachos is fun to watch." (Instagram)
"Great place to watch a game and drink huge beers." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Disgusting. The definition of Flavor Town is just salt.
If you have a hangover, this is heaven. Otherwise avoid.

embedding_text: Guy Fieri's Vegas Kitchen in Las Vegas, USA. restaurant. tourist_trap. Culinary equivalent of a monster truck rally. Viral 'Trash Can Nachos', but food is greasy, salty, and overpriced. Red flags: Grease overload, Expensive junk food. Positives: Trash Can Nachos, Loud fun.

name: Mona Lisa (The Louvre)
summary: While the Louvre is a gem, the Mona Lisa room specifically is a trap. You queue for an hour to get a 30-second glimpse of a tiny painting behind bulletproof glass from 10 feet away, surrounded by hundreds of phones.

red_flags.evidence: "The room is a zoo. People shoving to get a selfie." (Rick Steves)
"It's tiny and dark. The reflection on the glass ruins it." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "It is the most famous face in art history." (Louvre Guide)
"Turn around and look at the Wedding Feast at Cana. It's huge and empty." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Skip the line for Mona. Go see the Napoleon Apartments instead.
Underwhelming but you have to check the box.

embedding_text: Mona Lisa (The Louvre) in Paris, France. attraction. tourist_trap. Specific exhibit trap within a gem museum. Hour-long queues for a distant glimpse of a tiny painting behind glass. Mosh pit atmosphere. Red flags: Mosh pit viewing, Underwhelming reality. Positives: Most famous painting, Rest of museum is amazing.

name: Le Jules Verne (Eiffel Tower)
summary: Dining inside the Eiffel Tower sounds like a trap, but this Michelin-starred restaurant delivers. You get a private elevator, incredible views, and legitimate haute cuisine. Expensive, but offers value by combining entry, view, and fine dining.

red_flags.evidence: "Lunch starts at €140. It is a splurge." (Michelin Guide)
"Book 3 months out. Jacket required." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "Skipping the main tower line is worth €50 alone." (Travel Blog)
"Actually delicious, not just 'good for a tower'." (Eater)

sample_reviews.text: The most romantic meal of my life. Food was exquisite.
Expensive but you save time and hassle. Better than the other tower restaurants.

embedding_text: Le Jules Verne (Eiffel Tower) in Paris, France. restaurant. local_gem. Michelin-starred dining inside the tower. Private elevator, incredible views, and legitimate haute cuisine justify the high price. Red flags: Very expensive, Strict dress code. Positives: Private elevator access, Michelin star food.

name: Vatican Museums
summary: Contains some of the world's most important art (Sistine Chapel), but the experience is often miserable due to dangerous overcrowding and heat. It is a 'Must See' that feels like a trap due to mismanagement.

red_flags.evidence: "You are pushed along by the crowd. You cannot stop to look at art." (Guardian)
"People were fainting in the hallways. It is an oven." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "The Raphael Rooms and Sistine Chapel are pinnacle human achievements." (Art Forum)
"Pay extra for the 7am Key Master tour to see it empty." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: The art is 10/10, the experience is 0/10. I had a panic attack from the crowd.
Do the Friday night tour. Less people, cooler temperature.

embedding_text: Vatican Museums in Rome, Italy. attraction. mixed. World's most important art collection (Sistine Chapel) ruined by dangerous overcrowding and heat. 'Must See' that feels like a trap. Red flags: Cattle herding, No AC in summer. Positives: Unrivaled art collection, Early access tours work.

name: U Fleků
summary: Prague's oldest brewpub (1499). While the dark lager is historic and good, the venue is infamous for the 'Becherovka scam', where waiters place shots on your table without asking and then charge you for them.

red_flags.evidence: "Waiters drop trays of shots. If you touch it, you pay €5. Aggressive." (Honest Guide)
"Staff shout at you to tip. Very hostile." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "The beer is brewed on site and is delicious. Only available here." (Beer Advocate)
"The building is 500 years old and looks it. Accordion music is fun." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Beer is great, food is average. Watch out for the shot guy!
Trap. Locals go to Lokál instead for fresh beer and honest service.

embedding_text: U Fleků in Prague, Czech Republic. restaurant. tourist_trap. Oldest brewpub (1499). Historic dark lager is good, but infamous for 'Becherovka scam' (charging for unordered shots) and rude service. Red flags: Unordered shots scam, Rude service. Positives: Historic dark lager, Medieval hall.

name: Charles Bridge
summary: A stunning medieval bridge that is completely unusable during the day. It is a gauntlet of cheap souvenir stalls, caricaturists, and pickpockets. You cannot see the statues for the crowds.

red_flags.evidence: "You shuffle across. It takes 30 minutes to walk 500 meters." (Prague Morning)
"The 'artists' sell mass-produced junk. Ruins the vibe." (Honest Guide)

positive_signals.evidence: "Go at 5am. The mist on the river is unforgettable." (NatGeo)
"The blackened statues and Gothic towers are masterpieces." (UNESCO)

sample_reviews.text: Avoid between 9am and 9pm. It's a shopping mall on a bridge.
We went at dawn and had it to ourselves. One of the best moments of the trip.

embedding_text: Charles Bridge in Prague, Czech Republic. attraction. tourist_trap. Medieval bridge unusable during day due to crowds and trinket stalls. Gauntlet of pickpockets. Red flags: Impassable crowds, Cheap trinket stalls. Positives: Magical at sunrise, Architectural icon.

name: Széchenyi Thermal Bath
summary: The iconic yellow baths are the largest in Europe. While visually stunning, they are often dirty (hair in water), overcrowded, and confusing to navigate. 'Sparties' (bath parties) at night are notorious tourist traps.

red_flags.evidence: "Water was murky and full of floating hair. Changing rooms smelled." (TripAdvisor)
"Staff yell at you. Signs are unclear. Buying a ticket is a battle." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "Soaking in the outdoor pool surrounded by Neo-Baroque palace is epic." (Lonely Planet)
"Nothing else like it. Playing chess in the water is a memory." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Go to Rudas or Gellert instead. Cleaner and less crowded.
Gross changing rooms but the outdoor pool photo is worth it.

embedding_text: Széchenyi Thermal Bath in Budapest, Hungary. attraction. mixed. Iconic yellow baths. Visually stunning and unique, but often dirty, overcrowded, and confusing. 'Sparties' are traps. Red flags: Dirty water, Confusing and rude. Positives: Architectural beauty, Unique experience.

name: Szimpla Kert
summary: The original 'Ruin Bar'. Yes, it is full of tourists, but it is so massive, weird, and culturally significant that it transcends trap status. The decor (old trabant cars, bathtubs) is genuine art, and Sunday farmers markets are lovely.

red_flags.evidence: "Line down the street on weekends. Go early." (Budapest Flow)
"Drinks cost more here than other ruin bars, but entry is free." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "Every corner is an art installation. It birthed a genre." (Vice)
"On Sunday mornings, locals sell cheese and honey here. Totally different vibe." (We Love Budapest)

sample_reviews.text: Must see. Even if you don't drink, just walk through.
Crowded with Brits at night, but still the king of ruin bars.

embedding_text: Szimpla Kert in Budapest, Hungary. bar. local_gem. The original 'Ruin Bar'. Massive, weird, and culturally significant. Decor is art. Sunday farmers markets are authentic. Red flags: Nightly queue, Pricier drinks. Positives: Unmatched decor, Sunday Market.

name: Roberta's (Bushwick)
summary: The pizzeria that put Bushwick on the map. Despite becoming a global brand, the original bunker-like location remains excellent. The 'Bee Sting' pizza is iconic, and the hipster-industrial vibe is authentic to the neighborhood.

red_flags.evidence: "2 hour wait on weekends. No reservations for small groups." (Infatuation)
"Deep in Brooklyn. A trek for tourists staying in Manhattan." (Lonely Planet)

positive_signals.evidence: "Sopressata and honey combo is legendary." (Eater NY)
"Tiki bar in the back, garden, radio station. It's a compound." (The New Yorker)

sample_reviews.text: The pizza lives up to the hype. Dough is chewy and charred.
Don't wait 2 hours. Go to the Domino Park outpost if you just want the food.

embedding_text: Roberta's (Bushwick) in New York, USA. restaurant. local_gem. Pizzeria that put Bushwick on the map. 'Bee Sting' pizza is iconic. Hipster-industrial vibe is authentic. Red flags: Long waits, Out of the way. Positives: Bee Sting Pizza, Cool vibe.

name: In-N-Out Burger
summary: The definitive West Coast fast food. Tourists flock to it, but so do locals, chefs, and celebrities. The menu never changes, the prices are incredibly low, and the ingredients are fresh. A rare hype-beast that delivers.

red_flags.evidence: "Drive-thru can take 30 minutes. It wraps around the block." (LA Times)
"The fries are bad unless you get them 'Animal Style' or well-done." (Serious Eats)

positive_signals.evidence: "Double-Double for under $5 is the best deal in LA." (Eater LA)
"Secret menu items transform the meal." (Thrillist)

sample_reviews.text: It's just a burger, but it's a perfect burger for the price.
Fries taste like cardboard. Burger is fresh though.

embedding_text: In-N-Out Burger in Los Angeles, USA. restaurant. local_gem. Definitive West Coast fast food. Menu never changes, prices are low, ingredients fresh. Fries are polarizing. Red flags: Drive-thru lines, Polarizing fries. Positives: Cheap, Animal Style.

name: Russ & Daughters
summary: An appetizing shop (now with a cafe) serving the city's best smoked fish since 1914. It is pricey, but the quality of the lox, caviar, and herring is the benchmark for New York Jewish food.

red_flags.evidence: "Wait can be an hour just to buy bagels. Take a number." (NY Times)
"$20 for a bagel sandwich is steep, but it's loaded with fish." (Infatuation)

positive_signals.evidence: "The Gaspé Nova is silky, smoky perfection." (Bon Appetit)
"100 years of history in every bite. The staff are pros." (Serious Eats)

sample_reviews.text: The Super Heebster bagel is the best sandwich I've ever had.
Cafe wait was 2 hours. Go to the counter instead and eat in the park.

embedding_text: Russ & Daughters in New York, USA. restaurant. local_gem. Smoked fish institution since 1914. Pricey with long waits, but lox and herring are the benchmark for NY Jewish food. Red flags: Take-a-number wait, Premium pricing. Positives: Best lox in NYC, Family owned icon.

name: Naschmarkt
summary: Vienna's most famous market. The central aisle is a tourist trap of aggressive vendors selling overpriced falafel and olives. However, the Saturday Flea Market is legendary, and the perimeter restaurants (like NENI) are solid.

red_flags.evidence: "Vendors shove falafel in your face and demand you buy." (Vienna Unwrapped)
"Cheese and spices are double the supermarket price." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The antique market on Saturdays is a treasure hunt. Real vintage." (Lonely Planet)
"Sitting with a glass of Grüner Veltliner watching the crowd is nice." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Avoid the central lane. Just tourists being ripped off on olives.
NENI was delicious. Great Israeli food in the middle of the market.

embedding_text: Naschmarkt in Vienna, Austria. market. mixed. Vienna's famous market. Central aisle is a trap with aggressive vendors and overpriced goods. Saturday Flea Market and perimeter restaurants are excellent. Red flags: Aggressive sampling, Overpriced goods. Positives: Saturday Flea Market, Wine bars.

name: Samurai Restaurant (formerly Robot Restaurant)
summary: The successor to the famous Robot Restaurant, operating in the same Kabukicho location. Like the original, it's a neon-soaked cabaret with giant props and loud music. It is a pure tourist spectacle with steep ticket prices and zero cultural depth.

red_flags.evidence: "The bento box was cold, sad, and expensive. Eat beforehand." (Japan Guide)
"8000 Yen for a 90 minute show is steep." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "It's like being inside a seizure. Unique to Tokyo." (Travel Blog)
"The performers give 110%. It is wildly entertaining trash." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: The wildest thing I've ever seen. Don't eat the food, just drink beer and scream.
Headache inducing trap. Just a loud light show.

embedding_text: Samurai Restaurant (formerly Robot Restaurant) in Tokyo, Japan. attraction. tourist_trap. Successor to Robot Restaurant. Neon-soaked cabaret with giant props. Loud, chaotic, and culturally shallow. Pure tourist spectacle. Red flags: Inedible food, Expensive ticket. Positives: Visual overload, High energy.

name: Aguas Calientes Restaurants
summary: The town at the base of Machu Picchu is a captive market. Restaurants serve overpriced, mediocre alpaca pizzas and burgers to exhausted hikers. Service fees are often hidden, and quality is uniformly low.

red_flags.evidence: "Prices are 3x higher than Cusco for terrible food." (Lonely Planet)
"They frequently add a 10-20% 'service' charge plus cover charge that wasn't on the menu." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "It's the only place to eat after the train." (Travel Blog)
"Some spots have nice views of the rushing river." (Google Maps)

sample_reviews.text: Worst meal in Peru. Frozen pizza for $20. Total rip off.
We found a decent bakery (Boulangerie de Paris) but the rest is trash.

embedding_text: Aguas Calientes Restaurants in Aguas Calientes, Peru. restaurant. tourist_trap. Town at base of Machu Picchu. Captive market with overpriced, mediocre food (alpaca pizza). Hidden fees are common. Red flags: Captive market pricing, Hidden taxes. Positives: Convenience, River views.

name: Lombard Street
summary: The 'crookedest street in the world' is actually a traffic jam of rental cars. Residents hate the tourists who climb on their porches. It is a pretty photo, but driving down it is a stressful 45-minute wait for a 30-second descent.

red_flags.evidence: "Line of cars blocks the neighborhood. Idling fumes everywhere." (SF Gate)
"Residents are trying to charge a toll to discourage visitors." (CNN)

positive_signals.evidence: "View from the top looking at Coit Tower is spectacular." (TripAdvisor)
"The hydrangeas are beautiful in bloom." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Don't drive it. Walk it early in the morning. Driving is a trap.
Underwhelming. Just a curvy road with too many people.

embedding_text: Lombard Street in San Francisco, USA. attraction. tourist_trap. 'Crookedest street' is a traffic jam of rental cars. Residents hate the nuisance. Driving is stressful; walking offers better views. Red flags: Traffic nightmare, Nuisance. Positives: Great views, Flower gardens.

name: La Rambla Outdoor Restaurants
summary: The rows of outdoor terraces on La Rambla serve giant glasses of 'Sangria' (sugar and cheap wine) and 'Paellaador' (frozen industrial paella). It is the classic European tourist trap strip.

red_flags.evidence: "If you see photos of food on the menu, run. It's microwaved." (Culinary Backstreets)
"They serve you a 'bulldog' size drink without asking and charge €25." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "Sitting under the trees watching the world go by is nice." (Lonely Planet)
"Right in the middle of the action." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Avoid like the plague. Go to El Glop for real Paella.
Food was rubbery and tasteless. Waiter was rude when we didn't tip big.

embedding_text: La Rambla Outdoor Restaurants in Barcelona, Spain. restaurant. tourist_trap. Outdoor terraces serve frozen industrial paella and overpriced giant Sangrias. Classic European trap. Red flags: Frozen Paella, Giant drink scam. Positives: People watching, Central.
